repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Eric M. and Carol L. Meyers papers
did.abstract: Eric M. and Carol L. Meyers are professors in Duke University's Department of Religion. Throughout their careers, they have conducted archeological digs in relation to their interest in biblical and Judaic studies. The collection contains extensive materials related to several major excavations the pair conducted in Israel from the 1970s to the 1990s. The materials in the collection include binders and notebooks of field notes, charts, maps, and records; notecards; photographs (including slides, prints, and negatives), almost all black-and-white; a few audiovisual items; clippings; some administrative and correspondence files; coins; and drawings of sites and artifacts. There are many electronic files, some of which represent items not present in the collection. Topics include 20th century archaeology and practices; the Sepphoris, Meiron, Khirbet Shema, Nabratein, and Gush Halav excavation sites in Israel, including maps and photographs of the sites; Jewish and Arabic artifacts such as coins and pottery; other ancient artifacts; and religious and biblical studies as they relate to archaeology.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Eric M. and Carol L. Meyers are both professors in the Department of Religion at Duke University.

Eric M. Meyers joined Duke in 1969, after receiving his Ph.D. from Harvard University. Since joining the faculty of Duke, Eric Meyers has published extensively in the fields of biblical archeology and Judaism, often collaborating with wife Carol Meyers. He has also directed many archeological excavations in Israel and Italy. Eric Meyers is now Bernice and Morton Lerner Professor of Judaic Studies, and directs the Graduate Program in Religion.

Carol L. Meyers received her Ph.D. from Brandeis University, and joined Duke in 1977. Like her husband, Carol Meyers also focuses on biblical archeology and biblical studies, and is especially interested in the role of women in the biblical world. She has published widely, and directs many archeological excavations. She is Co-Director of Duke's Summer in Israel Program, and also directs undergraduate studies in the Duke Department of Religion. The holder of the Mary Grace Wilson Professorship in Religion, Carol Meyers is also an affiated faculty member in the Women Studies Program at Duke.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library reading room. To request access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use these records.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The list of contents was provided by the donor and contents have not been processed.
Original audiovisual materials are closed to use; copies must be made for access. Also, film negatives are closed to use; prints and electronic scans of these images may exist in the collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright for Official University records is held by Duke University; all other copyright is retained by the authors of items in these papers, or their descendants, as stipulated by United States copyright law.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Eric M. and Carol L. Meyers Papers were received by the University Archives as a gift in 1982; 1988; 1994; 2003; 2010; 2017; and 2019.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Eric M. and Carol L. Meyers papers, Duke University Archives, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection contains extensive materials related to several major excavations conducted by the Meyers and their teams in Israel from the 1970s to the 1990s, as well as materials related to later publications about their work. Formats include binders and notebooks of field notes, charts, and records; maps; notecards; photographs (including many slides, prints, and negatives); coins; news clippings; a few video and audio recordings; some administrative and correspondence files; and many drawings of sites and artifacts. There are also electronic records, most of which are black-and-white scans of photographs, negatives, and field notebooks, and drawings, many of these, but not all, are scans of items located in the collection.

Topics represented by the materials include 20th century archaeology and practices; the Sepphoris, Meiron, Khirbet Shema, Nabratein, and Gush Halav excavation sites in Israel, including maps and many photographs of the sites; Jewish and Arabic artifacts such as coins and pottery; other ancient artifacts; and religious and biblical studies as they relate to archaeology.

Materials have been kept in the binders and folders in which they were received. The collection is organized by accession number, but materials in separate accession number groups are intrinsically connected.
The addition (A2003-30) includes binders from an archeological dig in Gush Halav, and Arabic and Jewish coins from the Meiron and Khirbet Shema digs.
Accessions from 2010 and 2017 include materials from archeological digs in Nabratein, Meiron, Gush Halav, and Khirbet Shema.

The accessions from 2019 include materials from digs in Khirbet Shema, Gush Halav, Nabratein, Meiron, and Sepphoris, among other materials. Also received in 2019 are over 1200 digital files from the Sepphoris site, which have been migrated to a library server.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These materials contain information about the Meyerses' digs in Meiron and Khirbet Shema in Israel during the early and mid-1970s. These notes and records were later used as sources for two books co-written by the Meyerses, Excavations at Ancient Meiron, Upper Galilee, Israel 1971-72, 1974-75, 1977, and Ancient Synagogue Excavations at Khirbet Shema, Upper Galilee, Israel 1970-1972. The letters and numbers used to identify the various binders and folders (i.e. MV 4) indicate a particular physical part of the excavation site. Only some of the binders and folders are dated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These 6.5" x 9" registry cards were produced to document artifacts found at the Khirbet Shema and Meiron archeological sites in Israel in the 1970s. Some of the cards feature pencil drawings of the objects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These field notebooks from the Khirbet Shema excavation in Israel date from 1971. The letters and numbers used to identify the notebooks indicate specific physical places at the excavation site.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library reading room. To request access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use these records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series comprises eletronic files of scanned photographic images, fieldbooks, and illustrations, all relating to the archaeological work on the Sepphoris site in Israel by teams from Duke University, led by Carol and Eric Meyers, and Hebrew University. The majority of the scans represent physical objects found in the Meyers collection.

Series dates for electronic files indicate the creation date for the digital scans rather than the physical objects or images. Series descriptions were taken almost verbatim from donor-supplied notes received with the electronic files.

The photographic images, most of which are scans of physical prints and negatives in the Meyers collection, were taken by Sepphoris site team members from about 1984 to 1995, almost all in black-and-white. Most are of site excavations and objects found in situ; another much smaller group consists of Sepphoris artifacts photographed in the U.S. lab in 2011. The fieldbooks date from 1984 to 1997 and contain extensive notes as well as some photographs; this group also includes the 2000 Duke team final site reports in .pdf format. Many of the original field notebooks are in the collection at Hebrew University, thus the scans may be the only representation in the Meyers papers. The Sepphoris illustration archive contains scans of drawings and other work, some of which were used for the 2013 Duke publication on Sepphoris pottery.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library reading room. To request access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use these records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains scans of primarily ink drawings of artifacts excavated by the Duke team over the years. The scans should correlate with the data in the electronic spreadsheet file, also available in this series. The four main sub-folders are: 2011 and 2012 (from Yulia Rudman); Duke Drawings Archive; Hebrew U Archive Pottery Scans; and Studio Shots of Artifacts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are primarily ceramic artifacts that were set aside for drawing after the 2011 dig and a study season following that dig. Yulia Rudman is the Jerusalem-based artist who created them for the publication project team. The drawings were done digitally.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are scans of ink drawings stored in sleeves in large white binders in the Meyers papers. File names are meant to correspond with the labels on the sleeves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These scans were done in Jerusalem, as the inkings themselves are located there. A note to provide some context and background: The Hebrew University and Duke teams split around 1990, and at that point divided up the archaeological site they had been excavating into two fields: a Hebrew U field and a Duke field. The "Hebrew U Archive Pottery Scans" contains pottery drawings from both fields. Those that are under the proprietary domain of Hebrew U consist of any drawing with a registration number beginning with 84.3, 85.2, 86.1, 86.2, 86.3. (Those numbers are the excavation areas within the Hebrew U field.) These drawings are not included on the spreadsheet "Artifact Drawings and Photos Archive," because they were not used in the Duke publication project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: While most of the black-and-white photo archive consists of field photos, there are a several contact sheets with artifact photos. They are included in this sub-folder.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library reading room. To request access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use these records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains scans of most but not all field photographs located in the black-and-white photographic archive, taken at the Sepphoris site in Israel between 1984 and 1995. Sub-folders, referenced by three digits representing the year and the site, represent eight different excavation areas. The color photographs in the Meyers papers are only available in slide form (transparencies) and have never been scanned.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library reading room. To request access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use these records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are scans of the fieldbooks for the Sepphoris site excavations. These logs and notes were created by the area supervisors working for the dig team from approximately 1984 to 1997; includes the final site reports from 2000. Some of the fieldbooks exist at Duke only in digital form, as their hard copies are currently at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Other files represent physical copies in the collection. Some of these fieldbooks also contain Polaroid photographs that were affixed to the page of the book.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Electronic records in this series have been migrated to a library server and digital use copies can only be accessed onsite in the Rubenstein Library reading room. To request access, please contact the Rubenstein Library before coming to use these records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These scans derive from photographs taken in 2011 by Sean Burrus (former Duke graduate student) for his chapter on the small objects discovered at Sepphoris III. There are four sub-folders by material (bone, ceramic, metal, and stone) and the file names contain the artifact registration number. The catalog numbers for the objects, which appear in Sepphoris III, are different than the registration number.
